Topic.Title: EVERYONE WANTS SPRINT - NO ONE WANTS YAHOO!!!!

Message.Msg: Yahoo is NOT for sale. That has been clear since they rejected the MSFT offer. I was hoping that the new B of D would sell the company, but with yet again a new overpaid CEO, that isn't in the cards. Personally, I believe that Yahoo is a badly managed, badly directed, clueless company that is slowily losing its position in the cyber market. I do not believe it can be "turned around" without replacing many people starting at the "suit" level. The company also needs a complete change of attitude - ie ETHICS starting with issuing unlimited ID's to serial spammers and those making political posts on these boards so that they can inflate the number of actual people using Yahoo.

Topic.Title: Update your password recovery information

Message.Msg: Google does essentially the same thing. People lose / forget passwords all of the time. Figuring out how to restore that lost password has to be a major pain for companies (like Yahoo) where a password is the key to message posting, accessing portfolios, etc. Providing "recovery" information makes their job easier and safeguards your account. Stop complaining and give them the information

Message.Title: Why Sprint's Softbank Deal Is Good for Yahoo!
Message.Msg: One of the implications of this deal, some observers have concluded, is that SoftBank will now no longer be able to do a deal to buy back Yahoo!'s (YHOO) stake in Yahoo! Japan, which SoftBank also controls. Not so fast. There are several ways the Sprint deal could be good for Yahoo! shareholders. SoftBank is not using any of its cash to buy Sprint. SoftBank is financing the deal through a large loan of the same amount from several large Japanese banks. SoftBank's stock is currently worth $32 billion. It's up nearly 600% in the last 10 years. Part of that is growth, but part of that is appreciation in the yen. The yen is worth 33% more today than it was a decade ago, relative to the dollar. Japan has an inflated currency, and Softbank is embracing that -- even after SoftBank's stock has dropped 20% since Thursday on news of this deal. My point: This Sprint deal isn't draining their cash or their already strong stock price. SoftBank and its subsidiary, Yahoo! Japan, still have lots of cash to do a deal with Yahoo!. Softbank has about $10 billion in cash at the moment. Yahoo! Japan has another $3 billion. But why should SoftBank or Yahoo! Japan use any of their cash when the Japanese banks are hungrily looking for new loans to give out to good corporate clients? Just as they did for Sprint, the Japanese banks might be happy to provide the cash to finance the buyout of Yahoo!'s stake. How much cash would they need? Yahoo! Japan is currently worth $20 billion. Yahoo! has a 35% stake of that worth, ostensibly $7.2 billion.

Message.Title: DeCastro Leaves Google For COO Position at Yahoo!
Message.Msg: Yahoo! has hired high ranking Google executive Henrique de Castro. De Castro comes over from Google where he was vice president of Google’s worldwide Partner Business Solutions group. He had been with Google since 2006. De Castro will serve as Yahoo!’s Chief Operating Officer and will be responsible for strategic and operational management of Yahoo!'s worldwide sales, operations, and media and business development. De Castro will report directly to Chief Executive Marissa Mayer. He is scheduled to assume his new position by January 22, 2013.
